title: What is post secondary degree (its equivalent to Bachelors)? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the United States, all formal education after graduating from high school is called “post-secondary” education. It takes the form of (Caveats: this is not intended to be a comprehensive list; it is not in any order of preference; terminology may vary from state to state): Enrolling in a technical college or institute, with the intention of earning a certificate or diploma in one of the trades such as truck driving, plumbing, electrician, etc.Enrolling in a two-year college or community college with the intention of earning an associate’s (two-year) degree:as a reasonable end point to post-secondary education, oras a stepping stone to enrolling in a four-year college or university, with the intention of earning a bachelor’s degree.Enrolling directly (i.e. without going to a two-year college) in a four-year college or university, with the intention of earning a bachelor’s degree.So, earning a bachelor’s degree is simply one of the options within the broad umbrella of “post-secondary” education. Side note: Graduate work (or “post-graduate” work as it is called in some countries) may also be considered to be a form of post-secondary education, but that requires a person to have completed a bachelor’s degree first.

In the U.S., all degrees are post-secondary because secondary (high) schools do not award degrees, just diplomas. In the U.S., the following are the most commonly found levels of postsecondary degrees: Undergraduate Associate degrees (usually requiring at least two years of full-time study at an institution of higher education after secondary (high) school)Baccalaureate degrees (usually requiring at least four years of full-time study at a higher education institution after secondary (high) school or two additional years following an associate degree)Professional Degrees, e.g., M.D., D.D.S., J.D. (usually requiring three or more years of full-time study at a school of the particular profession [e.g., medical school, law school] following a baccalaureate degree) Graduate degrees Master’s degrees (usually requiring at least one year of full-time graduate-level study beyond a baccalaureate degree)Doctoral degrees, e.g., Ph.D (usually requiring three or more years of full-time graduate-level study after a baccalaureate degree and preparation of a dissertation making an original contribution to knowledge, or a similar project)
